text: The half-life is a statistical probability. In this sense, there is no 'history' of how long the particle has waited around to decay -- the chances of it decaying never change. There will always be a 50% chance that it will decay during any time span equaling its half-life. This is just as true for the first half-life as it is for the 70th half-life. If you have a statistically large number of such particles (say, a few million) there is almost certainly going to be half of them that decay every half-life. It won't be exactly half, but it will be very close to it.

text: Hypertonic solutions contain more solutes than isotonic solutions, which are basically 'neutral' solutions. So in order to even out the solutes (not the solvent), the solvent will move across the semipermeable membrane so that the solutes have more room to spread out. That's what osmosis is all about: spreading the solutes out by moving the solvent. If the water molecules from the hypertonic area flowed into the hypotonic area, it might maintain the balance of the solvent. text: the only way a solution can act as a buffer if it has some way of soaking up both added acid (H+) and added base (OH-). That is why a buffer needs to have significant amounts of both a weak acid AND its conjugate base. The weak acid can react with any added base to neutralize the base, and the conjugate base (which is a weak base) can react with any added acid to neutralize the acid. These reactions are how a buffer keeps the pH from changing too much when acids or bases are added. The reason why a weak acid alone is usually not a very good buffer is that by definition, weak acids don't dissociate very much in solution. So that means a weak acid solution (let's call it HA) contains mostly undissociated weak acid HA, and not much of the conjugate base, A-. So it won't be very good at soaking up added acid, and it won't make a good buffer. We can fix that by increasing the amount of A- in the solution, either by adding an external source of A- (usually by adding some salt that contains A-, perhaps NaA), or by adding some strong base like NaOH. The strong base reacts with HA to make water and A-, the conjugate base! So that's another way to increase the A- concentration, by neutralizing some of the weak acid HA (but not all of the HA, since we still need both HA and A- around to make a good buffer).
question: Where does the extra salt (conjugate base) come in?

But if you compare the actual EN values, oxygen is actually more electronegative than anything but fluorine, and tends to pull electrons away from even chlorine and the rest. Fluorine is always 1-, because it pulls hardest, and only wants one electron, while oxygen pulls almost as hard, and wants two electrons, so it is almost always 2-. It's also important to remember that in a pure element, the oxidation number is 0, *by definition*. text: sexual reproduction evolved via natural selection. Some very primitive form of sexual reproduction (probably just sharing DNA randomly between single cells) led to greater variation in one population vs another. On a population scale, sexual reproduction clearly offers a selective advantage. The new-found variation means that the population as a whole can thrive in a wider variety of conditions because individuals are less similar to each other and the population as a whole can therefore survive in a wider variety of conditions. For example, let's say there is a population of cells that normally can survive in only dry, hot conditions. Let's say that through random mutation (which is pretty rare), one member of that population develops an allele of a gene that allows it to survive in humid conditions, and another member develops an allele of a different gene that allows it to survive in cold conditions.
